description.narrative: The Strategic Plan 2013-2018 was premised on four thematic areas namely; Access to Justice; Legal Literacy; Gender-Based Violence and Advocacy. The program has empowered women and children from marginalized social sectors in Zambia, to know and actualise their human rights through legal aid representation, counseling, legal education and advocacy for policy and law reform. Some of the specific results attained are: -Under legal representation, NLACW defended the rights of under-privileged women and children through the provision of legal aid services exceeding the set target in some cases. 8,922 women and children were assisted with legal representation before the courts of law, legal advice and psychosocial support services;out of which 2,343 cases were filed before the courts and 81% of the cases were won on behalf of clients. Cases reported to the Clinic covered a broad spectrum of family law and gender-based violence. -NLACW's advocacy activities contributed to strengthening of policies and laws to protect women and children’s rights. Legislation that was revealed in the period included the marriage Act; Gender Equity and Equality Act; the amended Constitution; Intestate Succession Act and the legal aid policy. - A milestone achievement under GBV was NLACW's support to draft the rules of Court to operationalise the Anti-GBV Act. -Under the Legal Literacy programme - 61 radio programs; 16 TV programs; 58 community workshops; and 58 school workshops were conducted to raise awareness on women and children's rights using simplified literature in both English and local languages targeting men, women, children, community leaders and traditional court adjudicators. - To ensure people in remote areas also access legal services, 56 mobile clinics were conducted in communities where legal services were almost non-existent. The NLACW also supported the Women's movement by providing technical support whenever there were legal reforms or matters of public interest.
